technical-data.invention-title: Batteriepack mit linearem Spannungsprofil und SOC-Algorithmus, der für das Batteriepack gilt
Battery pack having linear voltage profile, and SOC algorithm applying to the battery pack
Bloc-batterie avec profil de tension linéaire, et algorithme d'état de charge à appliquer au bloc-batterie

address.street: Samsung SDI co., Ltd. 428-5, Gongse-dong Giheung-gu Yongin-si
Samsung SDI co., Ltd. 428-5, Gongse-dong Giheung-gu Yongin-si
Samsung SDI co., Ltd. 428-5, Gongse-dong Giheung-gu Yongin-si
Samsung SDI co., Ltd. 428-5, Gongse-dong Giheung-gu Yongin-si

abstract.p: A battery pack (100) is provide that comprises a rechargeable battery module (110), and a battery management system (120) for controlling charging/discharging of the battery module (110). The battery module (110) comprises a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile within at least part of the charging and discharging cycle of the battery module (110). The battery management system (120) is arranged to calculate a state of charge of the battery module (110) by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module (110).

A battery pack (100) is provide that comprises a rechargeable battery module (110), and a battery management system (120) for controlling charging/discharging of the battery module (110). The battery module (110) comprises a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile within at least part of the charging and discharging cycle of the battery module (110). The battery management system (120) is arranged to calculate a state of charge of the battery module (110) by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module (110).

description.p: The present invention relates to a battery pack and a state of charge (SOC) algorithm applied to the battery pack.

In general, a secondary battery is a battery that is rechargeable and dischargeable, unlike a primary battery that cannot be recharged. A secondary battery may be used as a single battery or may be used as a battery module that include a plurality of batteries as a unit, according to a kind of an external device to which the battery is applied.

Conventionally, a lead storage battery has been used as a power supply device for starting an engine. Recently, an idle stop and go (ISG) has been applied to improve fuel-efficiency, and has been distributed widely. A power supply device supporting the ISG system that is a system for restricting idle driving has to maintain strong high output property for starting an engine, rechargeable and dischargeable properties regardless of frequent engine stop/start, and long life span. However, when using a conventional lead storage battery, the rechargeable and dischargeable properties are degraded and the battery may not be used for a long time according to frequent engine stop and restart operations under the ISG system. Therefore, usage of lithium ion secondary batteries required under the ISG system is increasing, and usage of lithium ion secondary battery capable of generating high output is also increasing.

According to an aspect of the invention, there is provided a battery pack comprising: a rechargeable battery module; a battery management system for controlling charging/discharging of the battery module; wherein the battery module comprises a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile within at least part of the charging and discharging cycle of the battery module; wherein the battery management system is arranged to calculate a state of charge of the battery module by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module (110).

In some embodiments, the battery management system is arranged to calculate a second state of charge of the battery module after a time period of charging or discharging by determining a first state of charge of the battery module and then using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module.

In some embodiments, the first state of charge is a current state of charge of the battery module and the second state of charge is a predicted state of charge of the battery module. In other embodiments, the first state of charge is a previous state of charge of the battery module and the second state of charge is a current state of charge of the battery module.
In some embodiments, the battery management system is arranged to determine the first state of charge of the battery module by measuring an output voltage of the battery module.
In some embodiments, the battery management system is arranged to determine the substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile.

In some embodiments, the battery management system is arranged to determine a charging and discharging voltage-time profile over a sub-range of state of charges, and then using this to determine the substantially linear voltage-time profile for a wider range of state of charges.

In some embodiments, the battery management system is arranged to use the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile to determine a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile.
In some embodiments, a charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile of the battery module is linear within a range of states of charges from 70% to 90% state of charge.

In some embodiments, the battery module comprises a lithium ion battery comprising a negative active material and a positive active material, optionally wherein the battery module consists of the lithium ion battery.
In some embodiments, the battery module comprises a lithium ion battery including carbon as the negative active material.

The negative active material may comprise soft carbon, and the negative active material comprises soft carbon and carbon black. In some embodiments, the soft carbon may form about 54.5 to 99.5% of the negative active material and the carbon black may form about 0.5 to 45.5% of the negative active material.

In some embodiments, the battery module comprises a combination of at least two selected from the group consisting of LixWO3, LixMoO2, LixTiS2, LixMoS2, LixMnO4, Li1-x Mn2O4, Li1-xNiO2, Li1-xCoO2, LiNiVO4, LiF, and LixNiyCozAl1-y-zO2 as the positive active material.

According to a second aspect of the present invention, there is provided a power apparatus for an idle stop and go system for starting an engine, comprising: a battery pack according to the first aspect; a power generating module for charging the battery module; a starter motor arranged to be powered by the discharge of the battery module.

In some embodiments, on starting the engine, the battery management system (120) is arranged to determine an engine start voltage value of the battery module (110) based on an elapsed time using the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile, and then using the engine start voltage value and the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile to determine an engine start state of charge value.
According to a third aspect of the present invention, there is provided a vehicle comprising a power apparatus according to the second aspect and an engine.

The invention now will be described more fully hereinafter with reference to the accompanying drawings, in which illustrative embodiments of the invention are shown. Embodiments of the present application will be described to the extent that one of ordinary persons skilled in the art would be able to carry out the invention. The various embodiments of the present invention are different from each other, but not exclude each other. For example, certain shapes, structures, and characteristics described in the specification may be modified without departing from the scope of the invention. Also, locations or arrangements of each component in each of the embodiments may be modified without departing from the scope of the invention. Therefore, this is not intended to limit the present invention to particular modes of practice, and it is to be appreciated that all changes, equivalents, and substitutes that do not depart from the technical scope of the present invention are encompassed in the present invention. Like numbers refer to like elements throughout.

Hereinafter, embodiments of the present invention will be described with reference to accompanying drawings so that one of ordinary persons skilled in the art would be able to carry out the invention.
FIG. 1 is a diagram showing a schematic configuration of a battery pack 100 according to an embodiment of the present invention, and connecting status to peripheral devices.

The battery pack 100 includes first and second terminals P1 and P2, and a battery module 110 connected between the first and second terminals P1 and P2 to receive a charging power and outputting a discharging power. The battery pack 100 may be electrically connected to a power generating module 210 and a starter motor 220 in parallel via the first and second terminals P1 and P2. In addition, the battery pack 100 includes a battery management system (BMS) 120 and a battery module 110 as shown in FIG. 1.

The battery pack 100 stores charging power generated by the power generating module 210, and may supply discharging power to the starter motor 220. For example, the power generating module 210 may be connected to an engine (not shown), and may be connected to a driving axis of the engine to convert a rotary driving force into an electric output. Here, the charging power generated by the power generating module 210 may be stored in the battery module 110 via the first and second terminals P1 and P2 of the battery pack 100. For example, the power generating module 210 may include a direct current (DC) generator (not shown) or an alternating current (AC) generator (not shown), and a rectifier (not shown), and may supply a DC voltage about 15 V, for example, about 14.6 V to 14.8 V. In other embodiments, the power generating module 210 may include other features.

For example, the battery pack 100 may be used as a power device for starting an engine of an idle stop & go (ISG) system for improving fuel-efficiency. Since stop and re-start of the engine are frequently repeated in the ISG system, the charging and discharging of the battery pack 100 are repeated.

A life span of the lead storage battery that is conventionally applied in the ISG system is reduced due to the frequent repetition of the charging and discharging operations, and the charging and discharging characteristics degrade. For example, a charging capacity may be reduced due to the repetition of the charging and discharging operations, thereby reducing startability of the engine and reducing replacement period of the lead storage battery.

However, the battery module 110 of this embodiment includes a lithium ion battery maintaining constantly charging and discharging characteristics and having less aging when compared with the lead storage battery, and accordingly, may be applied suitably to the ISG system in which the stop and re-start of the engine are frequently repeated. In addition, since the lithium ion battery has less weight than that of the lead storage battery having the same charging capacity, the fuel-efficiency may be improved. Also, the same charging capacity may be achieved with less volume than that of the lead storage battery, a mounting space may be saved. However, the battery module 110 of the present invention is not limited to using a lithium ion battery, and other embodiments of the invention may include different types of batteries, such as a nickel metal hydride (NiMH) battery.

The battery module 110 may include a plurality of battery cells (not shown) that are connected to each other in serial and parallel with each other, and a rated charging voltage and charging capacity may be adjusted by combining the serial and parallel connection.

The battery module 110 is a common name for structures including a plurality of battery sub-units. For example, when the battery pack 20 is a battery rack including a plurality of battery trays, the battery rack may be referred to as a battery module 110. Likewise, when a battery tray includes a plurality of battery cells, the battery tray may be referred to as a battery module 110.

The battery module 110 of this embodiment includes a lithium ion battery including an electrode assembly including a positive electrode plate including a positive active material, a negative electrode plate including a negative active material, and a separation film, and a case receiving the electrode assembly. Here, the positive active material may be a combination of at least a plurality of positive active materials, in more detail, may include a combination of at least two selected from the group consisting of LixWO3, LixMoO2, LixTiS2, LixMoS2, LixMnO4, Li1-xMn2O4, Li1-xNiO2, Li1-xCoO2, LiNiVO4, LiF, and LixNiyCozAl1-y-zO2.

In addition, a negative electrode may be formed of a material including carbon. The negative electrode of the battery module 110 according to some embodiments of the invention may include soft carbon and carbon black. In more detail, the portion of negative active material of the battery module 110 may be the soft carbon of about 54.5 to 99.5% and the carbon black of about 0.5 to 45.5%. In other embodiments, other materials for the negative electrode may be used.

Also, the separation film is disposed between the positive electrode plate and the negative electrode plate, and is an insulating thin film having a high ion transmittance and mechanical strength. Pores of the separation film have a diameter of about 0.01 to 10 µm, and a thickness of the separation film is generally about 5 to 300 µm. The separation film may be formed of, for example, olefin-based polymer having chemical resistance and hydrophobic property, a sheet or non-woven fabric formed of glass fiber or polyethylene, or craft paper. The separation film that is currently in market is a cell-guard based film, a polypropylene separation film, or polyethylene-based separation film.

In particular, the battery module 110 of some embodiments of the invention may include the lithium ion battery including soft carbon as the negative active material. The battery module 110 including the soft carbon may have charging and discharging voltage profiles that are linealy in proportional to a state of charge (SOC) of the battery module 110 according to characteristics of the material. In more detail, the lithium ion battery including the soft carbon at the negative electrode according to this embodiment has linear charging and discharging voltage profiles within 70 to 90% SOC band that is mainly used by vehicles. When the charging and discharging are performed at a high speed due to the characteristics of the lithium ion battery, the battery module 110 including the soft carbon according to this embodiment of the present invention has the linear charging and discharging profiles.

FIGS. 2A and 2B are graphs schematically showing charging and discharging voltage profiles of a conventional lithium ion battery and charging and discharging voltage profiles of the lithium ion battery of an embodiment of the invention.

Referring to FIG. 2A, the charging/discharging voltage profiles of the conventional lithium ion battery show a curvature as shown in the graph. That is, as shown in the graph, the charging/discharging voltage profiles of the conventional lithium ion battery have a rapid inclination at an initial stage of the charging or discharging, and may not have linearity.

On the other hand, FIG. 2B is a graph showing the charging/discharging voltage profiles of the lithium ion battery including the soft carbon as the negative active material according to this embodiment. As shown in the graph of FIG. 2B, when the lithium ion battery includes the soft carbon as the negative active material, the charging/discharging voltage profiles are linear throughout the entire section. In particular, the lithium ion battery of this embodiment has the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles even when the high output is maintained in a section of SOC 70 to 90% where the battery of a vehicle is mainly used. That is, even when the battery module 110 of a vehicle of the ISG system has the high output characteristic, according to the lithium ion battery using the soft carbon as the negative active material, the SOC may be grasped easily due to the linear charging/discharging voltages without using a complex current integrating algorithm. Therefore, since the charging/discharging graph is linear, the SOC may be identified via an open circuit voltage.

Next, the BMS 120 monitors a state of the battery and controls the charging/discharging operations. In his embodiment, the BMS 120 calculates the SOC by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the lithium ion battery that uses the soft carbon as the negative active material. Functions and operations of the BMS 120 will be described in detail later.

Next, the power generating module 210 may include an alternator of a vehicle. The alternator supplies the charging power to the battery pack 100, and may supply electric power to an electric load 230 that will be described later during driving the engine.

Next, the starter motor 220 is driven when starting the vehicle, and may supply an initial rotating power for rotating the driving axis of the engine. For example, the starter motor 220 receives the electric power stored in the battery pack 100 via the first and second terminals P1 and P2, and re-drives the engine by rotating the driving axis when starting the engine or re-starting the engine after idle stop. In more detail, the starter motor 220 provides the engine with an initial rotating power when a user starts the engine of the vehicle or in an idle go status.

Meanwhile, the electric load 230 may be connected to the battery pack 100 with the power generating module 210 and the starter motor 220. The electric load 230 consumes the electric power stored in the battery pack 100, and may receive the discharging power stored in the battery pack 100 via the first and second terminals P1 and P2 and may includes various vehicle electric devices.

The electric load 230 may include a car air-conditioner, a radio, and a remote controller receiving terminal; however, the embodiments of the present invention are not limited thereto, and the electric load 230 may refer to loads that are driven when receiving an electric power from the power generating module 210 or the battery module 110. In the charging/discharging voltage profiles shown in FIGS. 2A and 2B, when the number of used electric loads 230 increases, a discharging gradient of the graph becomes greater.

Hereinafter, general functions of the BMS 120 and a method of acquiring the linear SOC characteristic of the battery module 110 according to time and relational characteristic between the SOC and charging/discharging voltage profiles by the BMS 120 and, on other way, providing the SOC of the battery module 110 according to the acquired characteristics without a complex calculation operation will be described.

The BMS 120 of this embodiment is connected to the battery module 110, and controls the charging and discharging operations of the battery module 10. In addition, the BMS 120 may perform functions such as an over-charging protection, an over-discharging protection, an over-current protection, an over-voltage protection, an overheat protection, and a cell-balancing function. To do this, the BMS 120 may include a measuring unit for measuring the voltage, the current, the temperature, the remaining electric power, the life span, and the SOC from the battery module 110, and may control external devices, that is, the starter motor 220 and the power generating module 210, by generating control signals based on the measurement results.

The BMS 120 may use an SOC determination method such as a voltage measuring method, a current integrating method, and a current integrating and a Kalman filter application method in order to determine the SOC. In particular, in this embodiment of the present invention, the BMS 120 may predict the SOC of the battery module 110 without using the above described SOC determination method that is complex, using the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles of the lithium ion battery using the soft carbon as the negative active material. This will be described in more detail with reference to FIG. 3.
FIG. 3 is a block diagram of the BMS 120 for acquiring the SOC according to an embodiment of the present invention.
Referring to FIG. 3, the BMS 120 includes a battery characteristic acquiring unit 121, a monitoring unit 122, an SOC prediction unit 123, and an output profile providing unit 124.

First, the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 acquires linear charging and discharging characteristics of the battery module 110. As described above, the lithium ion secondary battery including the soft carbon as the negative active material has the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles according to this embodiment of the present invention. By using the above characteristic, the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 may grasp the linear charging and discharging characteristics so that SOC prediction unit 123 can predict the SOC of the battery module 110. The battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 may refer to data showing the battery characteristics input in advance, or may refer to data recording the SOC according to time by repeatedly performing the charging/discharging operations directly.
FIGS. 4A through 4C are diagrams showing experimental data and graphs about the lithium ion battery according to an embodiment of the present invention.

Referring to FIGS. 4A through 4C, FIG. 4A shows data representing the SOC and voltage values of the lithium ion battery having the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles according to time, FIG. 4B is a graph showing the data of FIG. 4A with respect to the SOC and the voltage, and FIG. 4C is a graph showing the data of FIG. 4A with respect to the time and the SOC.

FIG. 4A shows data representing the SOC and the voltages of the battery module 110 after charging the battery module 110 including the soft carbon as the negative active material at 0.2C and 1C per second. As a reference, #1 and #2 show the number of experiments, and the graph shows an average of the experiments #1 and #2. Referring to the graph of FIG. 4B, the voltage profiles of the battery module 110 have linearity except for a partial section. In particular, the graph shows the linearity within a section between 70% and 90% that is the SOC band mainly used by the vehicle.

The lithium ion battery including the soft carbon as the negative active material according to this embodiment of the present invention has the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles as shown in FIG. 4B, and the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 may acquire the SOC of the entire voltage section by using a relationship between the SOC-voltage in a partial section of the profile. By using the above feature, the SOC with respect to the voltage value within the entire section of the profile (or at least the entire useable section of the profile) may be acquired based on the voltage value of a partial section of the profile.

Also, referring to the graph of FIG. 4C, the battery module 110 of this present invention has the linear SOC characteristic that is proportion to time. By using the above feature, the SOC characteristic in proportion of time can be predicted by deriving the relationship between the SOC and time in a partial section of the SOC-time profile.

Although the charging voltage graph is only shown in FIGS. 4B and 4C, the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 acquires the discharging voltage characteristics of the battery module 110. The discharging voltage characteristics are determined according to engine efficiency and characteristics of the electric loads in the vehicle in which the battery module 110 is mounted. In a vehicle of the ISG system, the start and re-start of the engine happen frequently, and thus, an output profile may be obtained by using the linear SOC characteristic.

In particular, the lithium ion battery of this embodiment of the present invention has the linearity in the SOC band of 70 to 90% that is mainly used by the vehicle, and thus, the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 acquires the voltages of the SOC section between 70% and 90%. Since a power generator, that is, an alternator, is connected to the battery module 110 used in a vehicle to continuously charge the battery module 110, the SOC of the battery module 110 is generally maintained at 70% or greater. In addition, since the battery module 110 is continuously discharged due to the starter motor 220 and the electric loads 230 in the vehicle, the SOC of the battery module 110 is generally maintained at 90% or less. However, the above description is about the SOC section where the battery module 110 of the vehicle is mainly used, and the embodiments of the present invention are not limited to the above range.

Next, the monitoring unit 122 monitors a state of the battery module 110 having the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles. To do this, the monitoring unit 122 continuously checks an output voltage and an output current used by the battery module 110. In addition, the monitoring unit 122 checks elapsed time during the charging or the discharging operation so that the SOC prediction unit 123 and the output profile providing unit 124 may acquire prediction values based on the data of the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121.

Next, the SOC prediction unit 123 predicts the current SOC of the battery module 110 based on the data of the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121. As described above, although the lithium ion battery has the high output property, it is difficult to obtain the SOC through the current integrating algorithm every time due to the frequent outputs of the vehicle of the ISG system. Therefore, the SOC prediction unit 123 may predict the SOC by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module.

In more detail, since the lithium ion battery including the soft carbon according to this embodiment of the present invention maintains the linearity of voltage profile within the 70 to 90% of the SOC band that is mainly used by the vehicle, the SOC may be obtained only by using the time information based on the charging/discharging voltage profiles in this mainly used section.

As described above, the lithium ion battery including the soft carbon according to this embodiment of the present invention has the linear SOC characteristic that is in proportion to the voltage profiles and in proportion to the time even under the high output condition in the vehicle of the ISG system. Therefore, the SOC prediction unit 123 may predict SOC by voltage profile information or time information.

In addition, the SOC prediction unit 123 of this embodiment may acquire the SOC based on the charging/discharging voltage profiles provided from the output profile providing unit 124 that will be described later. Since the lithium ion battery of this embodiment also derives the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles in proportion to time, the SOC prediction unit 123 may predict the SOC corresponding to the charging/discharging voltage values that is predicted only by the time information.

The output profile providing unit 124 provides the SOC prediction unit 123 with the output profile by using the characteristic of the charging/discharging voltage profiles that they vary linearity according to time. Since the lithium ion battery of this embodiment has the linear charging/discharging voltage profiles, the charging/discharging output profiles according to time may be provided based on the data of the battery characteristic acquiring unit 121 without monitoring the voltage in real-time using the monitoring unit 122. For example, since the battery module 110 of this embodiment has the linear charging/discharging voltage characteristic with respect to time, a voltage value after a predetermined time has passed since the engine stops may be predicted only by using time information. In other words, if the linear charging/discharging voltage characteristic with respect to time is know, then it is possible to predict a voltage after an elapsed time without directly measuring the new voltage after the elapsed time. Also, the output profile providing unit 124 may rapidly provide the output profile when starting the engine, by using the linearity even when the battery module 110 operates under the high output condition. The output profile acquired by the output profile providing unit 124 is used for the SOC prediction unit 123 to predict the SOC based on the charging/discharging voltages.
FIG. 5 is a flowchart illustrating processes of deriving a SOC value by the BMS 120 according to an embodiment of the present invention.

Referring to FIG. 5, the BMS 120 acquires the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module 110 (S11). Since the battery module 110 of this present embodiment includes the lithium ion batteries including the soft carbon as the negative active material, the battery module 110 has the linear charging/discharging characteristics. In other embodiments, other types of batteries having linear charging/discharging characteristics could be used.
Next, the SOC characteristic of the battery module 110 that is in proportional to the time is acquired (S12).
Next, input of the time when the SOC is wanted to be obtained is received (S13). In other words, the time at which it is desired to predict a new SOC is received.

Then, the SOC of the battery module 110 corresponding to the input time is output by a simple calculation using the linear characteristic (S14). Hence, according to the flowchart of FIG. 5 the BMS 120 can predict a new SOC using a simple calculation method.
FIG. 6 is a flowchart illustrating processes of obtaining a SOC value by the BMS 120 when starting the engine.
Referring to FIG. 6, the charging/discharging voltage profile of the battery module 110, which is in proportion to the time, is acquired (S21).
Then, the SOC of the battery module 110 in proportion to the charging/discharging voltage profile is acquired (S22). In other words the profile of SOC against voltage is obtained.

Next, a voltage value of the battery module 110 corresponding to an elapsed time is acquired by using the information of step S21, when the user starts engine (S23). In other words, in step S23 the voltage value of battery module corresponding to an elapsed time is acquired using the information of step S21 when the user starts the engine. In some embodiments, the elapsed time is the time since the engine was last stopped.

Next, the SOC corresponding to the voltage value of the battery module 110 is acquired by using information of step S22 (S24). In other words, the SOC of the battery module corresponding to the acquired voltage value is acquired using the information of step S22.

As described above, in embodiments of the invention there is provided a battery pack 100 comprising a rechargeable battery module 110, a battery management system 120 for controlling charging/discharging of the battery module 110, in which the battery module 110 comprises a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile within at least part of the charging and discharging cycle of the battery module 110. The battery management system 120 is arranged to calculate a state of charge of the battery module 110 by using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module 110. Thus a simple calculation method is possible.

In such embodiments, the battery management system 120 can be arranged to calculate a second state of charge of the battery module 110 after a time period of charging or discharging by determining a first state of charge of the battery module 110 and then using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module 110. The first state of charge could be a current state of charge of the battery module 110 and the second state of charge could be a predicted state of charge of the battery module 110. Alternatively, in a different mode of operation, the first state of charge could be a previous state of charge of the battery module 110 and the second state of charge could be a current state of charge of the battery module 110.
The battery management system 120 can be arranged to determine the first state of charge of the battery module 110 by measuring an output voltage of the battery module 110.

In some embodiments, the battery management system 120 can be arranged to determine a charging and discharging voltage-time profile over a sub-range of state of charges (e.g. 70% to 90%), and then to use this to determine the substantially linear voltage-time profile for a wider range of state of charges.

In some embodiments, the battery management system 120 can use the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile to determine a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile.

In some embodiments, the battery pack forms part of a power apparatus for an idle stop and go system for starting an engine. In some such embodiments, on starting the engine, the battery management system 120 can be arranged to determine an engine start voltage value of the battery module 110 based on an elapsed time using the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile, and then using the engine start voltage value and the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile to determine an engine start state of charge value.

While the present invention has been particularly shown and described with reference to exemplary embodiments thereof, it will be understood by those of ordinary skill in the art that various changes in form and details may be made therein without departing from the scope of the present invention as defined by the following claims.

Therefore, although a few embodiments of the present invention have been shown and described, it would be appreciated by those skilled in the art that changes may be made in these exemplary embodiments without departing from the principles and spirit of the invention, the scope of which is defined in the claims and their equivalents.

claim.claim-text: A battery pack (100) according to claim 1, wherein the battery management system (120) is arranged to calculate a second state of charge of the battery module (110) after a time period of charging or discharging by determining a first state of charge of the battery module (110) and then using the linear charging/discharging characteristics of the battery module (110).

A battery pack (100) according to claim 2, wherein: the first state of charge is a current state of charge of the battery module (110) and the second state of charge is a predicted state of charge of the battery module (110); or the first state of charge is a previous state of charge of the battery module (110) and the second state of charge is a current state of charge of the battery module (110).

A battery pack (100) according to any one of claims 1 to 3, wherein the battery management system (120) is arranged to determine the first state of charge of the battery module (110) by measuring an output voltage of the battery module (110).

A battery pack (100) according to any one of claims 1 to 4, wherein the battery management system (120) is arranged to determine the substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile.

A battery pack (100) according to claim 5, wherein the battery management system (120) is arranged to determine a charging and discharging voltage-time profile over a sub-range of state of charges, and then using this to determine the substantially linear voltage-time profile for a wider range of state of charges.

A battery pack (100) according to claim 5 or 6, wherein the battery management system (120) is arranged to use the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile to determine a substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile.

A battery pack (100) according to any one of claims 1 to 7, wherein a charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile of the battery module (100) is linear within a range of states of charges from 70% to 90% state of charge.

A battery pack (100) according to any one of claims 1 to 8, wherein the battery module (110) comprises a lithium ion battery comprising a negative active material and a positive active material, optionally wherein the battery module (110) consists of the lithium ion battery.
A power apparatus according to claim 9, wherein the battery module (110) comprises a lithium ion battery including carbon as the negative active material.

A power apparatus according to claim 10, wherein the negative active material comprises soft carbon, optionally wherein the negative active material comprises soft carbon and carbon black, further optionally wherein the soft carbon forms about 54.5 to 99.5% and the carbon black about 0.5 to 45.5% of the negative active material.

A power apparatus according to any one of claims 9 to 11, wherein the battery module (110) comprises a combination of at least two selected from the group consisting of LixWO3, LixMoO2, LixTiS2, LixMoS2, LixMnO4, Li1-xMn2O4, Li1-xNiO2, Li1-x CoO2, LiNiVO4, LiF, and LixNiyCozAl1-y-zO2 as the positive active material.

A power apparatus according to claim 13 when dependent on claim 7, wherein on starting the engine, the battery management system (120) is arranged to determine an engine start voltage value of the battery module (110) based on an elapsed time using the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-time profile, and then using the engine start voltage value and the determined substantially linear charging and discharging voltage-state of charge profile to determine an engine start state of charge value.
A vehicle comprising: a power apparatus according to claim 13 or 14, a engine.
